learn.title: The T.C.R.E.I. Framework
learn.subtitle: Master the art of prompt engineering with these core principles.

task.title: T - Task Definition
task.subtitle: Start Writing Prompts Like a Pro
task.description: Clearly define the specific action you want the AI to perform. This is the foundation of a great prompt.

content.title: Be Specific
content.text: Instead of "write about dogs", try "write a 500-word blog post about the benefits of owning a golden retriever for a family with young children".

content.title: Assign a Persona
content.text: Give the AI a role to play. This dramatically improves the tone, style, and expertise of the response.

content.title: Define the Format
content.text: Tell the AI exactly how you want the output structured. This saves you time and effort in post-processing.

context.title: C - Context Provision
context.subtitle: The More Details, The Better
context.description: Provide comprehensive background information to guide the AI towards a more relevant and accurate response.

content.title: Include Background Info
content.text: Give the AI the necessary details it needs to understand the situation. Think about who, what, where, when, and why.

content.title: Set the Scene
content.text: Describe the environment or scenario. This is crucial for creative writing, marketing copy, or problem-solving tasks.

content.title: Define Constraints
content.text: Are there any limitations or rules the AI must follow? Mention word counts, tone restrictions, or information to avoid.

references.title: R - References & Examples
references.subtitle: Show, Don't Just Tell
references.description: Provide examples (few-shot prompting) to demonstrate the desired output style, format, and quality.

content.title: Zero-Shot
content.text: No examples provided. The AI relies solely on its training data. Good for simple, direct tasks.

content.title: One-Shot
content.text: One example provided. This helps guide the AI towards a specific format or style.

content.title: Few-Shot (Optimal)
content.text: Provide 2-5 high-quality examples. This is the sweet spot for complex tasks, ensuring consistency and accuracy.

evaluation.title: E - Evaluation Techniques
evaluation.subtitle: Human in the Loop
evaluation.description: Critically assess the AI's output for accuracy, bias, and hallucinations. Your judgment is essential.

content.title: Detect Hallucinations
content.text: AI models can invent facts, sources, or details. Always verify critical information from a reliable source.

content.title: Identify Bias
content.text: Be aware of potential gender, racial, or cultural biases in the output. Prompt for neutrality if needed.

content.title: Use Quality Rubrics
content.text: Create a simple checklist to evaluate responses against your criteria for accuracy, tone, format, and completeness.

iteration.title: I - Iteration Strategies
iteration.subtitle: Always Be Iterating (ABI)
iteration.description: Refine your prompt based on the output. The first attempt is rarely perfect. Iteration is key to mastery.

content.title: Revisit the Framework
content.text: Is the Task clear? Is there enough Context? Can you add a Reference? Could the Persona be more specific?

content.title: Split into Shorter Sentences
content.text: Break down complex prompts into smaller, more manageable parts. This can often lead to better, more focused results.

content.title: Try Different Phrasing
content.text: Rephrase your request using different words or an analogy. Sometimes a small change in wording can unlock a better response.

content.title: Introduce Constraints
content.text: If the output is too broad, add limitations to narrow the focus and guide the AI more effectively.

builder.title: Prompt Builder
builder.subtitle: Craft the perfect prompt using the T.C.R.E.I. framework.
builder.task_description: Define the AI's role and what you want it to do. Be specific!
builder.task_placeholder: e.g., Write a short, exciting blog post about the launch of a new electric car...

task_examples.title: Examples of good task definitions:
task_examples.example1: Write a 500-word blog post comparing React and Vue. The persona is a senior software engineer. Format the output as a markdown table with columns for Feature, Benefit, and Use Case.
task_examples.example2: Generate three distinct marketing slogans for a new eco-friendly coffee brand. The tone should be witty and memorable. Format as a numbered list.

builder.context_description: Provide background info. Who is the audience? What is the goal?
builder.context_placeholder: e.g., The audience is tech enthusiasts. The goal is to generate hype. The tone should be futuristic and bold.

context_examples.title: Examples of good context:
context_examples.example1: The target audience for this blog post is beginners in machine learning. The goal is to provide a simple, easy-to-understand explanation of a complex topic. The tone should be encouraging and avoid technical jargon.
context_examples.example2: This email is to a potential investor. The relationship is formal. The goal is to secure a follow-up meeting. The key points to include are our unique value proposition, recent traction, and a clear call to action for a 15-minute call next week.

builder.references_description: Show the AI what you want with 1-3 examples (optional but recommended).
builder.references_placeholder:
e.g., Example 1: 'Headline: The Future is Now. Body: A sleek new EV just dropped...'
Example 2: 'Headline: Feel the Power. Body: Experience the thrill of electric speed...'

references_examples.title: Examples of good references (few-shot):
references_examples.example1:
Translate to Spanish:
sea otter -> nutria marina
platypus -> ornitorrinco
walrus -> morsa
narwhal -> ?
references_examples.example2:
Sentiment analysis:
Text: 'I love this new phone!' -> Sentiment: Positive
Text: 'The battery life is terrible.' -> Sentiment: Negative
Text: 'It's an average device.' -> Sentiment: ?
